items.title: Live: Heatwave sends temperatures soaring across Australia's south-east
items.description: A record-breaking heatwave is impacting south-east Australia, with temperatures expected to soar in parts of Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales. Follow our live coverage.

items.title: Two people with life-threatening injuries after light plane crash
items.description: Police and emergency services are at the scene of a light plane crash at an airfield on the Gold Coast's northern outskirts.

items.title: Trump could rein in ICE operation as shooting outrage intensifies
items.description: The Trump administration indicates it could rein in its Minnesota immigration crackdown as public outrage intensifies after a federal agent killed a protester.

items.title: Live: Ley backer insists leadership speculation 'all sound and fury signifying nothing'
items.description: A backer of Sussan Ley has taken aim at the fevered speculation about a looming Liberal leadership challenge, dismissing it as "sound and fury signifying nothing". Follow live.

items.title: World's oldest wooden tools found in Greece, dating back 430,000 years

featured_image.name: Scientists recover the oldest wooden tools from a site in ...

items.description:
Two wooden artifacts found at an ancient lake shore in Greece have been confirmed as the oldest handheld wooden tools ever discovered, dating back 430,000 years and revealing that early human ancestors were crafting wooden implements long before the emergence of Homo sapiens.

The discovery, published January 26 in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, includes a digging stick and a smaller tool of unknown purpose. Both objects show clear evidence of intentional shaping by human hands.

items.title: How a peaceful Invasion Day gathering in Perth turned to chaos
items.description: Premier Roger Cook says the way an orderly protest was targeted "runs against the very heart of what it means to be Australian". So what really happened in Perth's CBD on Australia Day?

items.title: Texas police urge 'wanted' Australian to hand himself in as sightings reported
items.description: Texan authorities say an extradition order may be required to resolve the "legal limbo" involving Australian man Izaak Michell.

items.title: NATO chief says Europe 'cannot defend itself' without US

featured_image.name: NATO boss Rutte slaps down calls for European army prompted ...

items.description:
NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte delivered a blunt message to European lawmakers on Monday, insisting that the continent cannot defend itself without American military support and warning that any attempt to pursue strategic autonomy would require doubling defense spending and abandoning the US nuclear umbrella.

"If anyone thinks here that the European Union or Europe as a whole can defend itself without the US, keep on dreaming. You can't," Rutte told the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs and Committee on Security and Defence in Brussels. "We need each other."[1][2][3]

items.title: Iran-backed militias threaten action as US carrier nears

featured_image.name: USS Abraham Lincoln arrives in Middle East

items.description:
Yemen's Houthi rebels and Iraq's Kataib Hezbollah have issued coordinated threats of military action in support of Iran as the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier strike group enters Middle Eastern waters, raising fears that a potential U.S.-Iran confrontation could ignite a broader regional conflict.

The threats from Iran's proxy forces mark a departure from June 2025, when members of the so-called "axis of resistance" notably refrained from coming to Tehran's defense during a 12-day war with Israel that also saw U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

items.title: 'Sydney don't know what's next': TikTok account banned over Bondi attack posts
items.description: The social media giant deleted the account and a host of other profiles promoting Islamic State and other violent ideology only after questioning by the ABC last week.

items.title: Russia-Ukraine peace talks to continue in Abu Dhabi on Feb. 1

featured_image.name: Ukraine-Russia-US talks open in Abu Dhabi with territory as key issue

items.description:
The next round of trilateral peace negotiations between Russia, Ukraine, and the United States is set to take place on February 1 in Abu Dhabi, according to U.S. officials, following two days of talks that all sides described as constructive but which revealed deep divisions over territorial issues.[1][2][3]

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed Monday that another round of discussions is planned for next week, though he said the exact date is still being finalized. The upcoming talks will build on initial meetings held January 23-24 in the United Arab Emirates capital, marking the first trilateral format in months to include political and military representatives from all three countries.[4][5][6][7][8]

items.title: The problem gnawing at China's economy
items.description: Unlike many Western economies, Chinese households stash away more than 40 per cent of their income. But the pressure to boost local consumption is mounting for Beijing.

items.title: 'Astonishing' purge leaves Xi Jinping almost alone at the top of the world's biggest army
items.description: Another two senior generals are under investigation for alleged corruption in China and that has big consequences for President Xi Jinping.

items.title: Gold miners surge as bullion tops $5,100, silver breaks $100

featured_image.name: Gold miner shares jump as bullion prices hit $5,100/oz record high

items.description:
Shares of major gold and silver miners surged in premarket trading on Monday as bullion prices smashed through historic thresholds, with gold topping $5,100 per ounce for the first time and silver extending its rally above $100.

The precious metals rally, fueled by geopolitical uncertainty and concerns about a potential U.S. government shutdown, sent investors rushing into safe-haven assets and the companies that mine them. Top miner Newmont rose 4.4%, while U.S.-listed shares of Barrick Mining climbed 3.8%, according to Reuters. Canadian miners Agnico Eagle Mines and Kinross Gold each gained 4% in premarket trading.[1][2]

items.title: USS Abraham Lincoln arrives near Iran as U.S. naval buildup intensifies

featured_image.name: US dispatches aircraft carrier to Middle East over ...

items.description:
The United States has escalated its pressure campaign on Iran, imposing fresh sanctions on nine vessels and their management firms while positioning the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier within striking distance of the Islamic Republic as tensions between Washington and Tehran reach their highest point in years.

The aircraft carrier arrived in the Middle East on Sunday evening near Iran, according to Israel's Channel 13. The arrival of the Abraham Lincoln Carrier Strike Group, accompanied by guided-missile destroyers and missile defense systems being deployed to the region, represents what President Donald Trump has called a U.S. "armada" approaching Iran.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: India, EU conclude 18 years of free trade negotiations

featured_image.name: Successful India makes world more stable: EU chief

items.description:
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President António Costa stood alongside Indian leaders on Monday as chief guests at India's 77th Republic Day parade in New Delhi, marking the first time both EU heads have jointly attended the celebration. The visit comes as both sides prepare to formally announce the conclusion of negotiations on a free trade agreement at the 16th India-EU Summit on Tuesday.

India's Commerce Secretary Rajesh Agrawal confirmed Monday that the two sides have successfully wrapped up talks on the FTA, ending 18 years of negotiations that began in 2007, were suspended in 2013, and revived in 2022. "Negotiations have been successfully concluded. The deal has been finalised," Agrawal said, adding that legal review of the text is underway and both sides aim to sign the pact this year, with implementation expected early next year.[1][2][3]

items.title: UK and Germany to build first direct offshore wind power link
items.description:
Britain's National Grid and Germany's TenneT announced on Monday a partnership to develop an offshore wind interconnector in the North Sea, the first direct power link between wind farms in the two countries.

The announcement came as ten European nations gathered at the North Sea Summit in Hamburg, where they signed the Hamburg Declaration pledging to deliver 100 gigawatts of joint offshore wind projects by 2050 in a bid to reduce reliance on fossil fuels.

items.title: Webb telescope produces most detailed dark matter map ever

featured_image.name: James Webb creates the largest map of the deep Universe

items.description:
Astronomers have produced the highest-resolution map of dark matter ever created, using data from NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. The new map, published January 26 in Nature Astronomy, confirms with unprecedented clarity how dark matter's gravity shaped the structure of the cosmos by drawing normal matter toward it throughout billions of years of cosmic history.[1][2]

The research, led by scientists from Durham University in the United Kingdom and Northeastern University in the United States as part of the COSMOS-Web collaboration, analyzed Webb observations of a section of sky about 2.5 times larger than the full moon in the constellation Sextans.[3][1]

items.title: Microsoft launches Maia 200 AI chip to challenge Nvidia

featured_image.name: Prediction: This AI Chip Stock Will Outperform Nvidia Again in 2026

items.description:
Microsoft on Monday unveiled the Maia 200, its second-generation in-house artificial intelligence chip, marking an escalation in the growing competition among tech giants to reduce their reliance on Nvidia hardware.

The new accelerator comes online this week in a data center in Iowa, with plans for deployment at a second facility in Arizona, according to Reuters. Microsoft claims the chip, designed for AI inference workloads, delivers three times the FP4 performance of Amazon's third-generation Trainium processor and Alphabet's TPU offerings.[1][2][3]

items.title: Government agency deliberately broke law for years, federal watchdog finds
items.description: Services Australia has known it was not fully complying with new child support laws since 2019, according to a scathing report released by the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
